title: Monster Energy NASCAR models will keep risqué outfits despite criticism
text:
Updated at 2:13 p.m. ET 
Updated at 2:13 p.m. ET 
Monster Energy told ESPN Wednesday that its models at NASCAR races will keep the same outfits they wore this past weekend during race activities at Daytona. 
That's sure to upset some fans, who went on social media to criticize the women's outfits as too revealing. 
MORE: NASCAR fans upset over scantily-clad Monster Energy Girls 
Mitch Covington, Monster's vice president of sports marketing, told ESPN the outfits have been a part of the company's brand identity since the beginning. 
"Monster has always been about racing and girls, and that won't change," Covington said. "When we first started in NASCAR with Robby Gordon in 2009, our models today were conservatively dressed compared to what they had on back then." 
After Sunday's Advance Auto Parts Clash race at Daytona, NASCAR fans checked in on social media with some unflattering comments about the all-black outfits. The Monster victory lane girls look like hookers. What's up with that @NASCAR — Tyler Scott (@TylerScott) February 19, 2017 https://t.co/cSYV5uBJBr . Evidently they don't watch the NFL or have seen a Peloton bike commercial! I say WeeHee!! Let's go racin' boys!!! — Larry The Cable Guy (@GitRDoneLarry) February 20, 2017 
Covington told ESPN the company had not discussed the issue with NASCAR, but he correctly noted that NASCAR race girls have worn even more revealing outfits in the sport's past, as some social media users noted. For the special few who were disturbed by the Victory Lane attire of the Monster Energy girls today, I offer a history lesson. #NothingNew pic.twitter.com/jxhKy4hYOI — Dave Moody (@DGodfatherMoody) February 19, 2017 
Monster Energy is in its first season as the title sponsor for NASCAR's premier series, in a sponsorship deal reportedly worth about $20 million per year. Watch This
